revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Amanita cokeri 52268.jpg | image_width = 234px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Amanitaceae]] | genus = ''[[Amanita]]'' | species = '''''A. cokeri''''' | binomial = ''Amanita cokeri'' | binomial_authority = (E.-J.Gilbert & [[Robert Kühner|Kühner]]) E.-J.Gilbert | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Lepidella cokeri'' E.-J.Gilbert & Kühner (1928)
''Aspidella cokeri'' (E.-J.Gilbert & Kühner) E.-J.Gilbert (1940) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Amanita cokeri'' | hymeniumType=gills | capShape = convex | whichGills = free | stipeCharacter=ring and volva | sporePrintColor=white | ecologicalType2=mycorrhizal | howEdible=poisonous}} {{stack end}} '''''Amanita cokeri''''', commonly known as '''Coker's Amanita''' and '''Solitary Lepidella''',{{cite book|last=McKnight|first=Kent H.|title=A field guide to mushrooms, North America|year=1987|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|location=Boston|isbn=0-395-42101-2|edition=2.|author2=McKnight, Vera B. McKnight |author3= illustrations by Vera B.|page=222}} is a [[mushroom]] in the [[Amanitaceae]] family. The mushroom is [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]].{{cite book |author=Miller HR, Miller OK. |title=North American Mushrooms: a Field Guide to Edible and Inedible Fungi |publisher=Falcon Guide |location=Guilford, Connecticut |year=2006 |page=46 |isbn=0-7627-3109-5}} First described as ''Lepidella cokeri'' in 1928, it was transferred to the genus ''[[Amanita]]'' in 1940. ==Taxonomy== ''A. cokeri'' was first described as ''Lepidella cokeri'' by mycologists E.-J.Gilbert and Robert Kühner in 1928. It was in 1940 when the species was transferred from genus ''Lepidella'' to ''[[Amanita]]'' by Gilbert.{{cite web |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=355702 |title=''Amanita cokeri'' (E.-J. Gilbert & Kühner) E.-J. Gilbert |publisher=International Mycological Association |work=MycoBank |accessdate=2011-03-01}} Presently, ''A. cokeri'' is placed under genus ''[[Amanita]]'' and subsection ''[[Lepidella]]''. The epithet ''cokeri'' is in honour of American mycologist and botanist [[William Chambers Coker]].{{cite book|last=Roody|first=William C.|title=Mushrooms of West Virginia and the Central Appalachians|year=2003|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|location=Lexington|isbn=0-8131-9039-8|page=50}}{{cite book|last=Bessette|first=A. E.|title=Mushrooms of the southeastern United States|year=2007|publisher=Syracuse Univ. Press|location=Syracuse|isbn=0-8156-3112-X|edition=1|page=106}} ==Description== [[File:Amanita.cokeri.004.COPY.jpg|thumb|left|Close view of gills. Also note the cap and stipe.]] Its [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is white in colour, and {{convert|7|-|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} across. It is oval to convex in shape. The surface is dry but sticky when wet. The cap surface is characterized by large pointed warts, white to brown in colour.{{cite web |url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/amanita_cokeri.html |title=''Amanita cokeri'' |author=Kuo M. |date=August 2003 |work=MushroomExpert.com |accessdate=2011-03-01}} [[Lamella (mycology)|Gill]]s are closely spaced and free from the stem. They are cream at first, but can turn white as the mushroom matures. Short-gills are frequent. [[stipe (mycology)|Stem]] is white, measuring {{convert|10|-|20|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1|-|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} thick. It tapers slightly to the top, smooth to shaggy in texture. There is a ring, thick and often double-edged, the underside being tissuelike. The universal veil hangs from the top of the stipe. The basal bulb is considerably large in size, with concentric circles of down-turned scales. The volval remnants stick to it and cause irregular patches.{{cite book|last=Fergus|first=C. Leonard|title=Common edible and poisonous mushrooms of the northeast|year=2003|publisher=Stackpole Books|location=Mechanicsburg|isbn=0-8117-2641-X|edition=1st|author2=Fergus, Charles|page=22}} Spores are white, elliptical and [[amyloid]]. They measure 11-14 x 6-9 [[micrometer|μ]], and feel smooth. [[Trama (mycology)|Flesh]] is white, and shows no change when exposed. There is no distinctive odour, but some specimens may develop the smell of decaying protein.{{cite web|last=Tulloss|first=RE|title=''Amanita cokeri''|url=http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita+cokeri|publisher=Amanitaceae.org|accessdate=24 October 2012}} ===Lookalikes=== ''[[Amanita solitaria]]'' is a closely related species, though a completely different European taxa.{{cite book|last=Fuller|first=Thomas C.|title=Poisonous plants of California|year=1986|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=0-520-05568-3|author2=McClintock, Elizabeth|page=43}} The notable similarity is that both it and ''A. cokeri'' are double-ringed.{{cite web|last=Tulloss|first=RE|title=''Amanita solitaria''|url=http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20solitaria|publisher=Amanitaceae.org|accessdate=24 October 2012}} ''[[Amanita timida|A. timida]]'', from the tropical South Asia, resembles ''A. cokeri'' in its volval structure, thick and notable ring and the large bulbal base.{{cite book|last=Bas|first=Cornelis|title=Morphology and subdivision of ''Amanita'' and a monograph on its section Lepidella|year=1969|page=390}}{{cite web|last=Tulloss|first=RE|title=''Amanita timida''|url=http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20timida|publisher=Amanitaceae.org|accessdate=24 October 2012}} ===Toxicity=== In a study, the presence of non-protein [[amino acid]]s 2-amino-3-cyclopropylbutanoic acid and 2-amino-5-chloro-4-pentenoic acid was revealed. The former acid was found to be toxic to the fungus ''[[Cercospora kikuchii]]'', the arthropod ''[[Oncopeltus fasciatus]]'' and the bacteria ''[[Agrobacterium tumefaciens]]'', ''[[Erwinia amylovora]]'', and ''[[Xanthomonas campestris]]''. The toxicity for bacteria could be eliminated by adding [[isoleucine]] to the medium. The other acid did not prove toxic.{{cite journal|last=Drehmel|first=Dennis C.|author2=Chilton, William Scott|title=Characterization and toxicity of ''Amanita cokeri'' extract|journal=Journal of Chemical Ecology|year=2002|volume=28|issue=2|pages=333–41|doi=10.1023/A:1017986108720|issn=0098-0331}} ==Habitat and distribution== ''A. cokeri'' inhabits mixed coniferous or deciduous woods and also grows on the ground. It grows mainly on oak and pine trees, and leaves a white deposit. It grows isolated or in groups.{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Roger|title=''Amanita cokeri''|url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5526.asp|publisher=Rogers Mushrooms|accessdate=24 October 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106115459/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5526.asp|archivedate=6 November 2011}} It is mostly distributed in southeastern North America.{{cite book|last=Gibbons|first=Whit|title=Poisonous plants and venomous animals of Alabama and adjoining states|year=1990|publisher=University of Alabama Press|location=Tuscaloosa|isbn=0-8173-0442-8|author2=Haynes, RR.|author3= Thomas, JL.|author4= with a foreword by Geller, Robert J.|page=28}} It fruits from July to November. ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[List of Amanita species|List of ''Amanita'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Amanitas}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1951851}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amanita Cokeri}} [[Category:Amanita|cokeri]] [[Category:Poisonous fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1928]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]]
